revised_title: Understanding the Mechanisms of Fatigue in Metals
tldr: The authors propose a quantitative theory of fatigue in metals, explaining how alternating stress and strain can cause progressive strain hardening, leading to the formation of cracks and eventual fracture. They argue that the presence of small cracks and structural inhomogeneities in metals cause stress concentrations, which, when combined with plastic deformation, can lead to fatigue failure. The authors also discuss the concept of safe and unsafe ranges of stress and the role of plastic strain in determining the endurance of materials under cyclic loading.
